;;T;;很多美国人;，法尼尔厅是圣地。它建于 1742 年，最初是一个市场和会议厅，后来成为波士顿市民生活的中心。在美国革命之前的几年里，市政厅会议变成了关于 1764 年糖税、1765 年印花税和茶叶税的辩论。正是在这里，像塞缪尔·亚当斯这样的波士顿人对他们眼中的英国压迫性政策表达了异议。后来，它成为反奴隶制倡导者举行集会并组织反对逃亡奴隶法的论坛。摆脱奴隶制的威廉·劳埃德·加里森和弗雷德里克·道格拉斯等废奴主义者发表了慷慨激昂的演讲。妇女参政论者还利用法尼尔厅来集会对妇女政治和社会权利的支持。

;
;;
;

;但是这座被称为“自由摇篮”的建筑，就像许多其他建筑一样美国历史上因奴隶制而伤痕累累。它的建造由彼得·法尼尔 (Peter Faneuil) 资助并以他的名字命名。彼得·法尼尔是一位拥​​有奴隶并从奴隶贸易中获利的富商，包括为前往非洲的船只提供部分融资。上个月，波士顿市议会通过了一项决议，要求该市给法尼尔厅一个更高贵的名字，比如“自由厅”，或者以被英国士兵杀害的非洲和土著血统的道格拉斯或克里斯普斯·阿塔克斯的名字重新命名。在波士顿大屠杀中。该决议毫无效力，因为只有市公共设施委员会才能重新命名该市拥有的建筑物。但这具有重要的象征意义。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;波士顿是最新一个考虑更改地标名称的城市。今年早些时候，美国军事机构开始更改陆军基地的名称，以指代南方邦联军官：布拉格堡更名为自由堡。海军将;;USS;;重新命名为;Chancellorsville;，以纪念南北战争黑人英雄罗伯特·斯莫尔斯（Robert Smalls）的胜利。据南方贫困法律中心统计，自 2015 年以来，超过 480 个南方邦联标志已被重新命名、移除或从公共场所移走。

;

;重命名法尼尔厅或许并不是一个显而易见的举动。删除南方邦联名称的论点更加明确，其中许多名称是在内战几十年后出现的，旨在加强种族隔离和吉姆·克劳法。考虑到这座建筑在创建美国和帮助废奴运动中所扮演的角色，彼得·法尼尔的情况要复杂一些。 “如果你不改变故事的存在方式，”波士顿非裔美国人历史博物馆的诺埃尔·特伦特说。楠塔基特岛，“如果你不改变人们对更名和围绕它的对话的认识，那么它的影响就很小。”

;

;波士顿法尼尔厅举办的关于奴隶制的新展览突出了个体奴隶，其中包括逃离法纳尔家族的“彼得”。它渴望向法尼尔厅的参观者（该建筑每年接待 1800 万人）介绍波士顿在奴隶贸易中的作用，以及奴隶们的生活方式。会议厅里悬挂着法尼尔的肖像。直到最近，游客们还以为他是这个国家的开国元勋之一。乔治华盛顿的肖像挂在附近。现在，有背景了。民权活动人士、前州代表拜伦·拉欣不愿意看到更名。 “根除它，就没有人会再问‘法尼尔是谁？’”;■;

;;;;美国国务院;自以色列和哈马斯战争爆发以来一直在加班加点在十月。国务卿安东尼·布林肯 (Antony Blinken) ;两次前往;中东，强调乔·拜登总统对以色列的支持，并敦促该国;在与哈马斯的战斗中保持克制;。但并非所有美国外交官都支持政府的立场。有报道称，国务院工作人员正在起草批评拜登政府处理战争方式的文件。新闻网站 Politico 报道称，一封正在征集签名的信要求美国支持停火并公开批评以色列。这样的“异议备忘录”不是普通的外交电报。为什么要创建异议渠道？它对影响政策的效果如何？

;

;严格来说，国务院员工必须执行政策，无论他们是否同意。如果他们不这样做，在不危及他们工作的情况下表达反对意见的最有效方式是发送异议电报，在电报中他们表达反对特定政策的理由。根据国务院的规定，外交官将此类电报发送给位于华盛顿的国务卿规划办公室，该办公室必须确认收到并将其向上传递，包括传递给国务卿。政策规划主任预计将在 30 至 60 天内做出答复。该部门的任何人都应该能够使用该渠道而不必担心受到惩罚；规则禁止报复。与大多数国务院记录一样，电报仅供内部使用。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;该频道创建于 1971 年，当时美国的越南战争导致国务院士气低落。 1968 年，266 名外交官员辞职，抗议林登·约翰逊总统下令采取的军事行动，而这些行动往往是秘密的。 1969 年接替约翰逊的理查德·尼克松 (Richard Nixon) 承诺公开进行战争，并“让持不同政见者参与政策讨论”。他还担心外交抱怨和敏感文件会被泄露给媒体。国务院内部的改革者提议设立异议渠道，作为安抚和管理不满情绪的一种方式。在尼克松的领导下，该部门采用了它。

;

;该机制很快就得到了测试。 1971 年 4 月，驻东巴基斯坦（当年晚些时候成为孟加拉国）总领事阿彻·布拉德（Archer Blood）发出了第一份异议备忘录。布拉德警告说，巴基斯坦军队在努力阻止东巴基斯坦脱离的同时，正在对该国的孟加拉人实施种族灭绝。他的备忘录指责美国未能谴责暴行和肇事者。然而，;“血液电报”;影响甚微。尼克松和他的国务卿;亨利基辛格将巴基斯坦领导人视为他们与中国沟通的渠道，并忽略了这份电报。布拉德的异议被公开。他被降职了。

;

;从那时起，几乎没有任何异议电报改变了政策。 1979 年的一张，反对残暴的;红色高棉;政权代表柬埔寨出席<小>;联合国;大会，说服国务卿改变路线，但遭到反驳。另一条呼吁张贴标志，警告美国人在泛美高速公路上旅行的危险，这一呼吁得到了落实。 2003 年，异议电报并没有阻止美国入侵伊拉克。2017 年 1 月，有人反对唐纳德·特朗普的一项行政命令，该命令;禁止从七个穆斯林占多数的国家前往美国;，吸引了 1,000 多个签名。但削弱该命令的是法院的挑战，而不是部门政策。拜登先生在 2021 年扭转了这一局面。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;纽约大学的汉娜·古尔曼 (Hannah Gurman) 《异议文件》一书的作者发现电缆泄漏已经变得更加普遍。 2021 年 8 月，《华尔街日报》报道称，美国驻阿富汗大使馆工作人员于 7 月发出了关于塔利班势力强大以及喀布尔即将崩溃的警告。共和党领导的国会委员会正在调查;美军混乱撤退;后来传唤了这份备忘录，并最终被允许查看。布林肯担心此举会产生“寒蝉效应”。然而，一些外交官反驳说，如果政策改变——而不仅仅是发泄情绪——是目标，那么强大的受众就会有所帮助。

;

;过去几周，随着有关国务院一位官员所说的“叛变”的消息不断传出，布林肯先生与员工组织了“倾听会”，并强调了“维持[并扩大异议和辩论的空间”。他可能是真诚的。正如该频道的一位创建者在 50 年前所说的那样，他可能还希望将异议保留在“内部”。 ;■;

;;A;阿布·阿纳斯 (Abu Anas) 是一位 40 多岁的聪明男人，两鬓已经开始灰白，他很高兴在 7 月份，他获得了在以色列工作的许可。在加沙，当他能找到工作时，他每天赚的钱不超过 10 美元；在以色列，他在建筑工地上赚的钱是他的十倍。和许多在以色列找到固定工作的加沙人一样，他在该国南部的一个贝都因阿拉伯城市拉哈特住了几个星期。 “战争开始时，我们很担心。我们感到不安全，”不愿让我使用他的真名的阿布·阿纳斯 (Abu Anas) 告诉我。

;

;几天来，他继续去上班，直到他对工作失去了希望。 “局势将会平静下来”。 10 月 11 日，以色列政府吊销了向 ;加沙居民;。现在，约有 10,000 名留在以色列的加沙人留在那里是非法的。但进入加沙的过境点已关闭，因此阿布·阿纳斯被困。

;

;;现在，大约 10,000 名身在以色列的加沙人留在那里是非法的。但进入加沙的过境点已经关闭;

;

;然后他的房东要求他离开。根据以色列法律，庇护非法巴勒斯坦人可能会被罚款或监禁。阿布·阿纳斯的房东建议他自愿到警察局报案，并要求被带到西岸。当阿布·阿纳斯和一群加沙人前往以色列警方时，大约一周;战争开始后;，他们被逮捕。阿布·阿纳斯说，他们的手机、随身物品和衣服被拿走，他们遭到搜查和殴打，并被关进一个拥挤的牢房，没有家具或床上用品，与其他大约 40 人一起;加沙人;。 （以色列警方发言人表示，他们无法对个别案件发表评论，但表示任何非法进入该国的加沙人都将被“合法逮捕”。）

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;第二天，他和其他一些加沙人被蒙上眼睛、戴上手铐，带上巴士，带到位于约旦河西岸的以色列军营兼监狱奥弗 (Ofer) ，拉马拉附近。据阿布·阿纳斯称，当他们到达时，他们被推倒在地，再次遭到殴打，并与其他 200 多名来自加沙的工人一起被安置在一个大帐篷里。 “我遇到了几个和我来自同一社区的人，”他说。他说，他们不被允许离开帐篷，但有些人了解到有几个类似的帐篷，里面也挤满了加沙工人。没有对他们被拘留作出任何解释，他们也无法联系律师或红十字会。

;;

;男人们睡在粗糙的木托盘上。雨水从帐篷的屋顶漏进来。阿布·阿纳斯 (Abu Anas) 随身携带的唯一衣服就是他被捕时穿的衣服。“我把它们洗了，然后把它们放回去晾干。”

;

;阿布·阿纳斯 (Abu Anas) 告诉我，他在奥弗 (Ofer) 被拘留了 15 天。 。然后他和其他一些人一起上了一辆公共汽车——他无法说出到底有多少人，因为他被蒙住了眼睛。他和其他大约十人被告知在通往巴勒斯坦权力机构管理地区拉马拉的道路上的一个检查站下车。他的<小>;身份证;文件被归还给他，但他的手机、钱和其他物品却没有归还。他被遗弃在陌生的环境中，身无分文，极度担心在加沙的家人。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;< p data-caps="initial">;;10 月 7 日后，帮助巴勒斯坦囚犯的以色列人权组织 HaMoked 的负责人杰西卡·蒙特尔 (Jessica Montell) 收到了数百名囚犯。一天打电话一次。其中一些来自加沙工人，他们受到惊吓并躲藏在以色列；其他人则来自与他们失去联系的加沙家人。

;

;“来自加沙的电话令人不寒而栗，”她告诉我。“你可以听到背景中的轰炸声。有时通话会突然中断。我的一位同事告诉我，她接到一位女士打来的电话，她急于寻找她的兄弟。她说‘我必须告诉他，他的儿子被杀了。’”

;

;;警察拿走了他们的衣服和物品，包括手机。他们殴打他们，然后将他们关进拥挤的牢房，没有家具或床上用品;

;

;HaMoked 收集了失踪的加沙工人的姓名和<小>;ID;号，并提交了一份;人身保护令;请求查明他们在哪里。媒体报道援引以色列国防军 (;IDF;) 官员的话说，有 4,000 名来自加沙的工人被军事拘留。

;

;在接下来的几周内，我们与三名工人交谈HaMoked 了解到，已获释的加沙工人被关押在三个地点——全都是军营。 HaMoked 采访的一名加沙人表示，他被关在“像鸡舍一样”的笼子里，暴露在外，没有食物、水、药物、床上用品或厕所。 ;以色列国防军;的一名发言人表示，“没有收到有关虐待和暴力的投诉……为被拘留者提供了住所以及全天的食物和水。此外，每个设施都有一支医疗团队。”

;;;

;10 月 7 日的袭击也引发了整个西岸的镇压。居住在那里的数百名巴勒斯坦人被逮捕，家人探视被停止，律师报告说，他们与客户的接触非常有限。

;

;与此同时，数千名加沙工人开始抵达约旦河西岸，其中一些被以色列警察或士兵扔在检查站；有些人向知道返程路线的司机支付了两倍或三倍的费用，以避开检查站，然后自己走了。拉马拉和比勒赫副省长哈姆丹·巴尔古提告诉我，截至11月初，西岸有6000名加沙工人，还有约100名加沙人在以色列和东耶路撒冷的医院接受治疗。他们被告知要和陪同他们的亲戚一起离开。他说，巴勒斯坦权力机构没有就滞留加沙人的问题与以色列当局进行任何沟通。 “这不是有组织的，”他告诉我。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;我在拉马拉的一个体育中心遇见了 Abu Anas ;（如图）; 巴勒斯坦权力机构在那里安置了大约 500 名加沙工人。这些男人——其中许多人穿着肮脏、破烂的牛仔裤或慢跑裤、T恤和运动衫——在大庭院里转来转去。当他们滚动浏览来自加沙的可怕消息时，他们用长满老茧的手捂住脸，低头咬着指甲，低头看着破裂的手机屏幕。志愿者分发装在聚苯乙烯蛤壳里的黄米和蔬菜饭菜。有些人在一排带手持淋浴的便携式厕所里洗澡。

;

;;“超过 80% 的男子都有被杀的亲戚。一个半小时前，有人得知他的全家——六个儿子和他的妻子——被杀了”;

;

;一名男子，一名训练有素的土木工程师，在;沙威玛工作< /i>; 在海法的一家餐厅里，他坐在泡沫床垫上，悲伤地看着手机。 “这里没有很好的互联网，”他告诉我。 “昨天我打电话给我的小女儿，我告诉她，这场战争结束后，我将带她和她的母亲去一家不错的餐厅和动物园。她告诉我，‘爸爸，我不需要那么多。我只想拥抱你，再次感到安全与平静。'”

;;;

;附近的另一名男子举起了手机，这样我就可以听到通知他的自动消息为了自己的安全，他从加沙北部撤离到南部。 “我三天前接到这个电话，尽管我在拉马拉，”他说。一位志愿者告诉我，“超过 80% 的人都有被杀害的亲戚。一个半小时前，有人得知他的全家——六个儿子和他的妻子——都被杀了。他晕倒了，我们叫了救护车。”

;

;阿布·阿纳斯有四个孩子：最小的一岁，最大的 12 岁。他们住在加沙南部的汗尤尼斯。 “我们的公寓仍然矗立着，”他告诉我，“但到处都被轰炸了，每个人都很害怕。”他说，为了保证安全，他的妻子和孩子四处走动，睡在不同的地方。 “那里很惨。”他必须借一部手机才能联系到家人。 “有时我不好意思问别人，”他告诉我。

;

;;他们说他们被殴打、蒙住头巾、用阿拉伯语辱骂……我看到了水泡和结痂，这是电缆的标志领带，绕在几个男人的手腕上;

;

;拱形体育馆内是一片杂乱的泡沫床垫海洋，上面堆满了毯子。装有物品的购物袋堆放在塑料凉鞋和卫生纸旁边。 Snaking wires connected phones to electricity sockets. Abu Anas surveyed the shipwreck. “All we talk about is how many massacres there were today, how many children killed, how many deaths. Of course we are angry. But we are not responsible for what happened. We didn't do anything. We were working with their permission. We are peaceful. I don't support violence from any party. Now we are prisoners here. We don't know what the future holds…No one feels safe because at any moment the Israelis can enter and arrest us.”

;

;I talked to dozens of Gazan workers who recounted different versions of the same story: fear of leaving their lodgings, price-gouging by drivers, difficulties in contacting their families in Gaza, loved ones killed or injured, relatives and friends who worked in Israel now missing, presumed detained.

;;;

;A month into the war, Gazan workers stranded in Israel were still arriving in the West Bank. One newcomer told me he had been hiding for four weeks in Nazareth, a largely Arab city in the north of Israel, waiting for an opportunity to cross to the West Bank without being seized by the police. I spoke to three men who told me that they had remained in their flat in Ramle, near Tel Aviv, for more than two weeks, while friends brought them food. Even then, they were arrested by police who raided their apartment one morning in the early hours. They said they had been beaten, hooded, abused with insults in Arabic, imprisoned in Ramle for four days and dumped at the Ramallah checkpoint. I saw blisters and scabs, the hallmarks of cable ties, around the wrists of several men. Some had been hospitalised in Ramallah as a result of their beatings.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;;T;he night I met Abu Anas, the Israeli government issued a press release. It said: “Israel is severing all contact with Gaza,” and that all Gazan workers in the country would be returned home.

;

;The following morning news outlets carried footage of around a hundred people returning to Gaza through the Kerem Shalom crossing at the south of the territory. Their hands were empty. Some didn't even have shoes. A day later I went back to see the Gazan workers in the sports complex. Several had heard through the grapevine of friends and relatives who had been transferred to Gaza.

;

;A man called Abu Adam told me his brother was one of those released. “I called my brother's wife and she passed me the phone and I was able to talk to my brother in Khan Younis [a refugee camp in Gaza].” Abu Adam said we were “happy” to see them leave. “We all want to return. I would prefer to be in Gaza, not here. There is my family, my children, my wife. If they should die and I remain alive here? It would be a life without meaning.” ;■;

;

;;Wendell Steavenson; has reported on the Iraq war, the Egyptian revolution and war in Ukraine. You can read her previous dispatches from Israel for ;1843 magazine;, and the rest of our coverage, ;here;.

; Sat, 11 Nov 2023 02:27:02 +0800 Germany’s Christian Democrats are unsure whom to hug | Europehttps://www.economist.com/europe/2023/11/09/germanys-christian-democrats-are-unsure-whom-to-hug ;
;
;

;;T;;his should; be a happy time for German conservatives. True, the Christian Democratic Union (;CDU;), the venerable right-of-centre party, has been out of power since Angela Merkel ended her 16-year reign as chancellor in 2021. But in just two years the ruling coalition, led by the left-of-centre Social Democrats (;SPD;), has withered in opinion polls (see chart). The three parties in government can now jointly muster barely 35%. The ;CDU ;and its Bavarian sister party by themselves command around 30%, a respectable rise from the 24% that they actually scored in the 2021 vote.

;
;;
;
;;

;The party has been doing well in recent local elections, too. In early October the ;CDU ;romped to victory in the central state of Hesse, scoring an eight-point surge to grab 35%. In Bavaria the Christian Social Union (;CSU;) retained the hold it has clamped on Germany's biggest state (by area) since 1957. “The majority of Germans now are voting for non-left parties,” says Jens Spahn, a ;CDU ;parliamentarian and former health minister.

;

;Yet far from being smug, the mood among mainstream conservatives is uneasy. Multiple challenges weigh down the ;CDU;. One is Mrs Merkel's legacy. The length of her dominance means that the party's successors as leaders inevitably look small by contrast; yet they remain damaged by some of her controversial policies, such as welcoming more than 1m refugees and phasing out nuclear power. A second challenge is that although the ;CDU ;is Germany's strongest party it still needs coalition partners. Conservative voters know that the most likely ones are all to the left. “They say, if I vote for you we'll just get a variant of the same old thing,” says Mr Spahn.

;

;In part because of those two challenges the ;CDU ;now faces a third: a growing threat from the populist far right. Often dismissed as marginal since its founding ten years ago, the anti-immigrant, anti-elite, anti-Europe and pro-Russia Alternative for Germany (;A;f;D;) has profited more than the ;CDU ;from disappointment with the government. Polls now suggest it is Germany's second-most-popular party, with nearly 22%. In three eastern states that will vote next year it is outpolling the ;CDU;. A seemingly pragmatic option would be a conservative alliance between the two. But most Germans, particularly in the more liberal west, view the ;A;f;D; with horror.

;

;So, officially, does the ;CDU;. Hendrik Wüst, a rising star in the party who was elected last year as minister-president of North Rhine-Westphalia, the most populous state, is categorical. The ;A;f;D; is not a democratic but a fascistic party, as ruled by the courts: “They put into question the foundations of our democracy, our freedoms, our attachment to the West, to Europe,” he says. “They are our opponent, not a potential ally.” Mr Wüst, who runs his state in coalition with the Greens, thinks the ;CDU ;should stick to its own core values and centrist instincts.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Friedrich Merz, the party's current national leader, also dismisses dealmaking with the ;A;f;D;. But his more conservative faction of the ;CDU ;has at the same time tried to steal the populist right's thunder by drumming on the same issues that appear to boost its support. The most obvious is immigration, a perpetual bugbear for the ;A;f;D;. Given an influx last year of 1m Ukrainian refugees, a big jump in the number of asylum-seekers from elsewhere and obsessive popular-media coverage of crimes attributed to foreigners, public fears of immigration have risen markedly.

;

;Mr Merz, a bespectacled former corporate lawyer, has helped stoke such fears, describing Ukrainian refugees as “benefit tourists”, implying that a Berlin district with many immigrants is no longer part of Germany, and dismissing the idea of accepting refugees from Gaza because “we have too many antisemites already.” Mr Spahn has also taken up the cudgels, asserting that people from “Muslim-Arab cultures” will make Germany more violent, and also suggesting that German authorities should use force to stop irregular immigration. “We need a simple recognition of the fact that ;wir schaffen das nicht mehr;,” he insists, pointedly contradicting the magnanimous declaration that “we can handle this” made by Mrs Merkel at the height of the Syrian refugee crisis of 2015.

;

;Such rhetoric resonates with a souring public mood, underlined by recent surveys showing that immigration currently tops voter concerns. But the ;CDU;'s adoption of hard-right talking points is risky, warns Julia Reuschenbach, a political scientist at the Free University of Berlin. In other European countries, centre-right parties that have similarly tried to outflank radical upstarts have in nearly every case ended up hurting themselves more. “Italy's conservatives tried to appease the far right and the result is that they no longer exist,” says Mr Reuschenbach. “In their place there are three far-right parties.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Tarik Abou-Chadi of Oxford University cites another strong example. In Bavaria's election Markus Söder, the ;CSU;'s popular and long-standing leader, ran a boisterous campaign attacking the ruling coalition in Berlin, and particularly the Greens, for their allegedly bossy ways and out-of-touch idealism. This did win new votes for conservatives; but they accrued not to the ;CSU ;but to the ;A;f;D; and the Free Voters, a local populist party. Together they surged to 30%, while the ;CSU ;just held steady at 37%. “The focus on culture wars simply allows and encourages the dominance of these issues in public discourse,” says Mr Abou-Chadi. “This helps to normalise the ;A;f;D;.”

;

;Mr Reuschenbach notes that by contrast, the ;CDU ;has performed strongly in recent state elections where it has emphasised competence and moderate conservative values. Mr Wüst would agree; his state is a prime example. “We can change and adapt,” he says, but only so long as this is “on the basis of our Christian values and on the attitudes of the middle class.”

;

;Given the nature of German politics, where it is impossible for any party to get an outright majority, and given the nature of a public that generally prefers calm assurance to stirred-up anger, the ;CDU ;needs to take care not to alienate potential coalition partners with harsh rhetoric. Even if German opinion is shifting a bit to the right, the ;CDU;'s only path to power is still through a deal with the left. By tilting right, Mr Merz only makes that harder. ;■;

; Sat, 11 Nov 2023 01:57:03 +0800 Why migration is in such a mess once more | Internationalhttps://www.economist.com/international/2023/11/09/why-migration-is-in-such-a-mess-once-more ;
;
;

;;I;;LLEGAL IMMIGRATION; is taxing governments on both sides of the Atlantic.西非和加那利群岛之间的海上移民路线，这条通道非常危险，多年来一直被避开，如今又重新投入使用：截至 2023 年，已有约 30,000 人尝试过境。德国等曾经对寻求庇护者友好的国家，正在削减福利并加速驱逐出境。今年，可能有 50 万人穿越达连峡（连接哥伦比亚和巴拿马的地峡的一部分）到达美国。这是 2010 年代尝试穿越的次数的四倍多。

;
;;
;
;;

;This human drama exists alongside a quieter increase in authorised migration. A recent report from the ;OECD;, a club mainly of rich countries, found that its 38 members accepted a record 6.1m immigrants permanently last year. ;The Economist;'s own calculations show immigration to rich countries increasing at its fastest pace in the 15-year period for which we have reliable data (see chart 1 ). Across the ;OECD;, around 10% of people live in countries they were not born in.

;

;The statistics derive from a range of factors pushing people to move, and to a host of enticements pulling them towards Western countries.就推动力而言，欧洲部分地区、中东和撒哈拉以南非洲地区的冲突正在驱使数百万人前往其他地方。 （大约 470 万乌克兰人逃离祖国，至少是暂时逃离祖国，前往欧洲。）极度贫困也促使人们迁移，犯罪和帮派暴力也是如此。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;;

;Now for the pulls.大多数移民，无论何种形式，都发生在区域内，而不是从贫穷国家流向富裕国家。但西方国家的相对安全是吸引移民前来的因素之一。富裕国家劳动力市场紧张是另一大吸引力。 Over 70% of migrants across the; OECD;'s countries are in work, a number that continues to climb. Average wages in the ;EU; are now over 12 times those in sub-Saharan Africa.

;

;The numbers wishing to migrate will only grow in the coming years.一些人担心气候变化可能引发人口外流。从富裕国家的角度来看，更大的担忧涉及人口结构：随着年龄的增长，他们将需要更多的进口劳动力。几十年来，富裕国家群的净移民占总人口的比例高于净出生人口的比例（见图2）。 Nearly 15m German residents, 18% of the population, are first-generation immigrants—a higher share than America at its peak in 1890.

;
;

;Diverging definitions

;

;Officials overseeing borders are struggling to navigate the situation—let alone the migrants trying to cross them.部分问题在于，人们移民旅程的复杂性模糊了国际法严格维护的区别。它是在难民（那些由于“有充分理由担心受到迫害”而无法返回原籍国并通过庇护系统寻求帮助的人）和其他移民之间进行的。 The numbers claiming asylum in; OECD ;countries last year reached a record high of 2m people. Tension builds because anyone arriving in a signatory country to the ;UN; Refugee Convention of 1951 may lodge an asylum claim.这阻碍了政府降低新移民数量的努力。

;

;What happens if someone fleeing misery also wants a job?有组织的劳动力移民计划规模太小，无法管理移民劳动力的供应或需求。这可能使庇护系统成为移民进入国家而不存在立即被驱逐出境风险的唯一渠道之一。由于资金不足和不堪重负，许多人都陷入了困境。富裕国家发现自己陷入了困境：如何平衡受人口结构和劳动力市场紧张困扰的经济体的需求与微妙的移民和庇护政治？

;

;Of church and state

;

;All these difficulties are on display in America.截至 9 月份的一年内，有创纪录的 240 万移民在南部边境被捕。该国的庇护制度已经摇摇欲坠。它积压了 200 万个案件，平均需要四年的时间来处理每个案件。 “我们没有向移民法官、庇护官员以及那些决定你抓到的人是否可以留下来的人投入资金，”曾在布什和奥巴马政府的国土安全部任职的特蕾莎·布朗说。

;

;Understanding how the composition of those arriving has changed illuminates the hardships pushing migrants towards the country.如今，立即向边境官员投降的家庭所占的比例比过去高得多。上个月，委内瑞拉人首次超过墨西哥人，成为在边境被捕的移民中人数最多的国籍。 They are exiles from the autocratic regime of Nicolás Maduro.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;One such is José Castillo, who is staying at a church shelter in San Diego.当他和其他移民每天外出寻找工作时，他们会将自己的物品装进垃圾袋，堆放在花园的帐篷下。圣母玛利亚的雕像矗立着。 Mr Castillo left his wife and two young daughters in Falcón state and then waited for months in Monterrey, in north Mexico, to make an asylum appointment with America's Customs and Border Protection via the; CBP; One phone app.

;

;The app tries to channel migrants into legal pathways, and reduce the numbers of would-be migrants crowding at America's southern border.但数字却让其管理陷入困境。去年推出的另一项计划为来自拉丁美洲和加勒比地区的某些拥有私人赞助商的公民提供两年的居留权，最初减少了来自这些国家的边境入境人数。 But it, too, has proved inadequate to meet demand.

;

;America's tight labour market—there are 9.6m job vacancies—is an obvious pull for migrants.卡斯蒂略先生是一名机械师，他解释说，他在加州一天赚的钱比在家里几个月赚的钱还要多。加州大学圣地亚哥分校名誉教授韦恩·科尼利厄斯认为，现在是移民在美国寻找工作的最佳时机。 In September the Biden administration granted temporary permission to nearly half a million Venezuelan immigrants to stay and work legally.

;

;That was done in part to ease the burden on beleaguered city governments like New York's, which wanted to grant asylum-seekers the right to work so that they could afford housing.但共和党人和民主党人也都发现了填补劳动力缺口的机会。美国的正式就业移民计划远远不足以满足公司对工人（无论是高技能工人还是其他工人）的需求。 The ;US; Chamber of Commerce reckons that in 2024 just one person will receive an ;H-1B; skilled work visa for every ten applicants. “政策辩论几乎完全没有考虑到劳动力市场的现实，”科尼利厄斯教授认为。

;

;Still, if you think America looks bad, try Europe.政客们再次在非法移民问题上互相争斗。整个原本无需护照的申根区已重新实施边境检查。各国政府正在重启离岸处理等可疑想法：本周，意大利右翼政府对一项协议表示欢迎，该协议将使阿尔巴尼亚接收一些寻求庇护者。

;

;Europe's difficulties run deeper than America's because it is not a unitary authority.无论将寻求庇护者分布在成员国之间看起来多么合理，一国或另一国政府总是会拒绝。 The ;EU;'s common asylum system does set common standards, but governments jealously guard their right to make asylum adjudications. Even the much-maligned “Dublin” system, under which asylum-seekers are supposed to be returned to the ;EU; country in which they first registered, is honoured largely in the breach. Last year Germany was able to return to other ;EU; countries only 6% of the asylum-seekers it considered eligible under the Dublin rules.

;

;The difficulty is that Europe, too, is crying out for workers.瓦伦·库马尔·贾恩 (Varun Kumar Jain) 的故事很有启发性。 2017年，他离开家乡印度东部的比哈尔邦前往华沙。他厌倦了比哈尔邦的酷热，同时也被波兰首都在他的领域缺乏竞争对手所吸引：印度烹饪。他很快就能将旅游签证转化为工作许可证。在一家印度餐厅里熬煮和切菜四年后，他刚刚开了自己的餐厅。他的孩子们在一所波兰学校上学，他则在该国唯一的锡克教寺庙上学。尽管存在强烈的反移民言论，但劳动力匮乏的波兰政府仍然导致此类移民大幅增长。

;

;Back in the old continent

;

;Ageing Europe will need ever more foreign workers for its growing labour-market needs owing to its demography. At 44 its median age is notably higher than America's, at 39. By one estimate the ;EU; would need to import 50m people over the next 25 years just to keep its population stable.随着劳动力短缺的加剧，富裕国家将加剧对移民的竞争，不仅是高技能移民，欧洲对护理人员、卡车司机和木匠的需求也巨大。

;
;;

;Although immigration cannot solve a country's demographic difficulties (because immigrants get old too), it can control the pace of change in the dependency ratio—the multiple of the economically dependent to working-age adults.这对欧洲至关重要（见图 3）。 “If managed well, the people on the move that are being scapegoated today will be eagerly sought after tomorrow,” says Amy Pope, director-general of the International Organisation for Migration, the ;UN;'s migration arm.

;

;Europe abuts a place where economic and political realities push people to leave.非洲的平均年龄为 19 岁。在整个非洲大陆，每年进入劳动力市场的 1000 万至 1200 万非洲人只能提供 300 万个正式工作岗位。大多数非洲移民在非洲大陆内流动，南非道路两旁的求职者游行就证明了这一点。第二批人，尤其是东非的人，在海湾石油国家获得了体面的收入，尽管他们的许多公民权利受到损害。 But a growing number make their way to Europe—and as Africa gets richer, more will acquire the means to do so.

;
;

;The journey ahead

;

;Failing to adjudicate properly between claimants undermines public support for all forms of migration, especially when labour migration is channelled through asylum systems.可以想象一种更理性的前进方式。需要资源充足的庇护系统以及量身定制的劳务移民计划，使新移民能够快速进入劳动力市场。这些内容应该足以改变人们原本计划进行未经授权的旅行的动机。但很难想象这样的计划能够规模大到足以容纳所有可能想要移民的人。 “I've become sceptical about the big promise that you can reduce irregular migration by increasing legal migration, because we create small legal trickles rather than large legal pathways,” says Victoria Rietig, a migration expert at the German Council on Foreign Relations, a research body in Berlin.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Canada and Australia offer interesting examples.这两个富裕国家都保持公众对极高移民率的支持（尽管并非没有麻烦）。去年，加拿大迎来了 100 万新移民，人口增长了近 3%。它占全球难民重新安置（直接将弱势难民转移到富裕国家）的 42%。澳大利亚又占了15%。但很难从他们的经验中推断出来。 It is their geography that helps them keep control, which in turn reduces incentives for others to come.

;

;In reality the sheer difficulty of managing migration is leading to official contortions.一方面，对庇护人数感到不安的政策制定者很乐意支持潜在的非法政策，例如海上抵制。另一方面，各国政府越来越开放地欢迎寻求庇护者进入劳动力市场。这可以采取明确的形式：德国一些州以“日益严重的劳动力短缺”为由，寻求给予寻求庇护者立即开始工作的权利，而不是花几个月的时间参加语言和融合课程。

;

;More often, though, governments offer labour-market integration through neglect.由于无法应对，不堪重负的庇护系统将申请人推入了法律困境。从那里，许多人会找到账外的工作，并希望他们的身份能够得到正规化；例如，在美国，很少有寻求庇护者要等待法律要求的 180 天或更长时间才能合法找到工作。最终，他们将能够获得社会保障号码和工作许可证，甚至在移民身份最终确定之前就正式进入劳动力市场。

;

;Frustration is leading other governments down tough paths. Confronted with unmanageable numbers of so-called spontaneous arrivals, some are increasingly reluctant to accept refugees via formal, often ;UN;-organised resettlement. 1980年，美国接纳了超过20万名重新安置的难民；去年，这一数字仅为 25,000 人。

;;

;Some on the political right have suggested rewriting or even tearing up the ;UN;'s Refugee Convention.与此同时，进步人士担心，该公约的条款五十多年来没有经过认真修订，过于狭窄，无法涵盖那些逃离暴力犯罪和赤贫的人们——例如中美洲或加勒比地区的部分地区。然而，美国智库移民政策研究所驻澳大利亚的全球研究员伊丽莎白·科利特指出，旧协议的灰烬中能否产生更好的协议绝非必然。事实上，仅仅展开讨论就可能导致取消对难民的保护。

;

;;A;;rrivals at; New Street station in Birmingham are greeted by a striking 24-metre-high atrium, a shopping complex and the fumes of diesel trains. The smell is an unpleasant reminder that just 38% of Britain's railway network is electrified, compared with 60% on average in the ;EU;.

;
;;
;

;That is nowhere near enough for the country's ;net-zero commitments;. The Railway Industry Association (;RIA;), a trade body, warned in 2021 that 448km of track must be electrified each year if all trains are to be green by 2050. That feat has been achieved only once since 1990.

;

;Britain's reliance on diesel is not just bad for the environment. Electric trains have more seats, and can accelerate and stop more quickly than their diesel cousins, speeding up journeys and increasing capacity on the network. They make travel cheaper due to lower maintenance and energy costs. A study by the ;RIA; found that an electric train costs up to £3m ($3.7m) less than a diesel one over its lifetime, and is 300% more reliable on suburban lines.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Two reasons explain this failure. The first, according to Tom Forth of the Data City, a startup that analyses the economy, is a spectacular lack of political will. Britain is the only big country in Europe that has no long-term electrification plan. Instead, the number of newly electrified kilometres fluctuates wildly as ministers' interest ebbs and flows. In Germany, where more than three-fifths of the network is electric, the government steadily electrified around 200km of track each year in the 40 years to 2019. The equivalent figure in Britain last year was 23km.

;

;The absence of an official plan pushes up already high capital costs, because workers cannot acquire the experience needed to manage ;big infrastructure projects;. Without the guarantee that expensive equipment will be reused the following year, construction companies often end up renting machines. “It's extremely ineffective,” complains Noel Dolphin, head of ;UK; projects at Furrer+Frey, a railway-electrification company. “We are very constrained by that boom-and-bust cycle.”

;

;The second reason why Britain struggles is that its railways are the oldest in the world. Costs are higher than elsewhere in Europe because tunnels and bridges often need repairs before overhead wires can be installed. During the electrification of the main route between south Wales and London, Network Rail, the publicly owned operator of railway infrastructure, spent about £20m, 7% of the project's cost, repairing a then 133-year-old tunnel.

;

;There is one exception to this gloomy picture—Scotland. The country is on track to decarbonise all passenger trains by 2035, largely because the devolved government has a long-term plan. “It's possible to electrify Victorian railways at a reasonable cost, as long as it's done with a rolling programme of electrification,” says Alex Hynes of Scotland's Railway, a partnership between Network Rail Scotland and the main train-operating company there.

;

;Progress in England is unlikely to accelerate soon. Many decisions have been put on hold until the creation of Great British Railways, a proposed state-owned body that will oversee all rail transport and absorb Network Rail. The people who run Birmingham's New Street station are not holding their breath: air purifiers are due to be tried out this year. ;■;

;;T;;HE STATE Opening; of Britain's Parliament, which took place on November 7th, is stuffed with pageantry. The most important is a nod to the English civil war. Black Rod, a stockinged flunkey, is dispatched to summon ;MP;s to listen to the king, only for the doors of the Commons to be slammed in her face. The message: His Majesty can wait. Parliamentarians run the show.

;
;;
;

;But how well are they doing? Parliament's basic job is to ;scrutinise legislation;, and ;MP;s are botching it. The trend in recent decades is for Parliament to sit for fewer and shorter days, and to spend less time poring over laws. Take the number of urgent questions, a showy procedure whereby a minister is summoned to the chamber to comment on the story ;du jour;. These have exploded, from four in 2007-08 to 104 in 2021-22. The time left over for scrutiny is squeezed.

;

;Brexit and covid-19 set precedents for ;legislating at speed; and handing wide powers to ministers, habits that governments find as addictive as monarchs once did. Vague “skeleton” bills let ministers fill in the gaps in laws later. Henry VIII clauses, which allow ministers to alter primary legislation by issuing regulations known as statutory instruments, crop up in the most mundane bills. Even the most consequential decisions can get cursory scrutiny. The obligation for net-zero carbon-dioxide emissions by 2050 became law in 2019 after only 90 minutes' debate in the Commons and without a vote among ;MP;s.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;This is objectionable in principle. Scholars have long argued that Britain's parliamentary system leaves the legislature at risk of being ridden over roughshod by the executive. And it is bad in practice, too. Drafting errors are on the rise; impact assessments of laws' expected costs and benefits are frequently cosmetic or missing altogether. Rushed legislation is invariably bad legislation. Take Boris Johnson's windfall tax on the oil-and-gas industry, which was driven through the Commons in a day and contained several big design flaws. Or Liz Truss's law to cap energy prices—similarly hasty and similarly sloppy. Giving ministers so much latitude to make amendments fuels uncertainty.

;

;This malaise strengthens the case for constitutional reform. Proportional representation would end one-party dominance of the Commons; an elected House of Lords would have a powerful mandate to halt badly drafted bills. But neither looks likely and both would entail profound changes in a country heartily sick of upheaval. Moreover, since the Lords is one of the few bits of Parliament still trying to do its job of fine-grained scrutiny, emptying the place risks being counterproductive.

;

;So simpler and quicker reforms should come first. Some are changes to process. Bill committees are meant to undertake line-by-line scrutiny of laws, but they are ad hoc and controlled by party whips. Putting them on a standing status, and picking their members by a secret ballot of ;MP;s, would give them clout and independence. The Commons should require all non-urgent bills to be published in draft form to iron out glitches and help ensure that policy ideas are fully developed. A Statutory Instruments Act should lay out principles for the use of primary and secondary legislation, and impose tighter scrutiny on regulations made under Henry VIII clauses.

;

;Other reforms should take aim at the people who make laws. Although it is a virtue of democracy that ;MP;s are generalists, amateurism goes too far. ;MP;s should be employing or commissioning experts in policy but their feeble budgets support only four full-time assistants; a representative to Congress in America can employ up to 18 full-time staff. The House of Lords would have greater clout if membership were no longer a bauble for party cronies; a strengthened appointments process could require nominees to meet a test of “conspicuous merit”.

;

;Fêtes accomplies

;

;But these changes can do only so much. The decline of parliamentary scrutiny reflects a malaise in British political culture. The cabinet should recognise that properly scrutinised legislation serves the country's needs better than showy, rushed lawmaking. Above all, ;MP;s must remember that their primary constitutional function is not to attend village fêtes and glad-hand constituents, but to be national legislators. This week's rituals were designed to signify that Parliament is sovereign. It should use that power to fix itself. ;■;
